regretList.regret: Dating someone in teenage years that changed the the course of my life for worse
I wish I would have taught my children better habits when it comes to their own health and wellness.

I resigned my job because my dad was going to die soon and I thought I’d be able to spend quality time with him. He died before my resignation took effect, and I did not ask for my job back. Fifteen years later, I still have feelings about not being invited by my employer to rescind the resignation, given the timing of my dad’s death.
getting married young (age 20)
I regret not continuing my piano lessons. I can play things through repetition, but I never gained the experience and knowledge necessary to become proficient.
Not studying abroad in college
1 theft charge at 17 years old. Minor punishment but record of crime follows me around despite being an upstanding citizen for the past 30 years. My Divorce.

I regret not waiting for my high school sweetheart.  He left for the Navy before I graduated high school.  It was so hard for me.  He was the only one in the world I felt loved me. I grew up neglected and longed for love.  I hated to see it go and I felt it was over once he left.  I chased loving feelings and started up with someone I could see and touch, although I loved him.  We talked as adults and he told me that he had every intention of marrying me, I told him that I wish he would've told me that at the time; but I can't be sure it would've made a difference.  I am glad that we had a chance to talk about this as adults though.  I apologized to him.  I didn't even consider how much I had hurt him with my actions, I selfishly only considered how I felt when he left.  He told me that he did it for us.  He wanted to be sure he could take care of us.  He's happily married, the guy I left him for is happily married.  I am sad and alone.
Not taking my undergraduate education more seriously.
I once hit my Dad..He NEVER hit me !
I regret not having invested anything as a teen or young person. I also regret not having kids.

Should get into shape
Not staying in touch with my ex and his family
I regret hiding from myself and others for so long.
Making decisions based upon fear or what seemed easier.
I wish I had been a better, more attentive mother. I was too overwhelmed with the challenges and didn't spend enough time on the joys of parenthood.

My first love was the Miss America title in 1966.  She asked me if she should.  I thought that would be cool. Unfortunately, I was in college in Eugene, she in Stockton.  We hardly ever got to see each other.  And, every time I could make it down there, the Pageant had big demands on her time.  I became jealous of the Pageant.  I said things I regretted that never should have been said which basically boiled down to choose this damn contest or me.  She choose the Pageant.  If I had kept my mouth shut she would have lost out at the Miss California level.  I learned important lessons about jealously and vowed never to be so again.  I had a second chance with her a decade or so later.  I was married at the time though and decided to stay where I was with my second love of my life.  Still I can't help wonder what could have been.

In college, I had a simultaneous relationship with two young women. Each knew about the other. I wish I'd had the courage to break up with one of them, to choose one of them. I was too afraid of hurting my longer-term girlfriend. Not deciding was an awful mistake and emblematic of problems throughout my life. Choosing might have set me on a totally different romantic track.
Getting married when I didn’t love the person.
Abusing alcohol for 45 years
ddddddddddddddddddddddddd

not making enough close friendships
Staying far too long in a bad marriage and not recognizing what was in-fact abusive behavior, that my children endured also.

I spent too much time away from my son when he was little. I was either partying or working out at the gym. If I could do it over again I would have stayed home and paid attention to him.  That’s time I’ll never get back and I regret it every damn day. I fucked up his childhood in so many ways.
I regret not graduating from college. I went four years but never finished.

I should not have caved to my mother when she insisted, "Either you have your sister-in-law as your matron-of-honor or there will be no wedding!" With all the grief I suffered through while SHE planned "my" (NOT!) wedding, I should have eloped and enjoyed a more meaningful, personal and loving wedding day.
not prioritizing my health when I was in college and the years following graduation.

I regret very little, however I do wonder what it would have been like if I launched my business at a younger age. I do hope this helps your statistical analysis which includes (what I would imagine would be a very low percentage) people who do not live life with regret.

I wish I had pushed myself to continue my doctorate degree.
Not maintaining fluency in French as my second language.

Making an ignorant, off-hand comment to someone else as a naive teenager.  And then taking too long to forgive myself for it as an adult.
Not going into the Airforce, I would have retired with 1000's of jet flight time. Regret that every time I'm an airline passenger.
spanking my child

My biggest regret is not saving for retirement sooner.  I should have "bit the bullet" and contributed first and I probably would have been in a better place now, in turns of finances.  The other item is that "quit" trying to get into Medical school.
Not enough focus as a high schooler/college student (too much other stuff).

I wish I had kept myself in shape.

I can see things in 3D and wanted to become an aircraft mechanic and attend the highly prestigious George T. Baker Aviation School in Miami, during my high school days. Instead, I went off to university and never got my hands dirty or the chance to fix airplanes.
pursuing a career path that i was "Expected" to take. not the one my heart told me to take.
That I did not complete law school when I had the opportunity and rather choosing to become a warrior in the business world and living my life for others rather than live my passion.
I wish I had not married the wrong person.

I only have one regret in life and that is not seeing my grandmother despite her asking me to come visit. She and I lived together for 6 months when I returned home from college while I was looking for a job. I got a job and she moved to my uncle’s house. My uncle’s family and I didn’t have a great relationship so I didn’t enjoy going to their house. She asked me many times to come visit but I told myself and her that work was so busy and the 12-hour shifts tiring. Two months later she passed. Wish I had the maturity at 22 to have set my feelings of discomfort aside for her and go see her.
Not learning Spanish

In 1996, I was studying abroad in Florence and I ended up responding to a sign in a local window "models wanted". Over the course of maybe a month or two, the artist painted me. The end result looked as much like as I did but the vibe/feel was exactly me. It was uncanny. But I wasn't a wealthy American student. I didn't have the money to buy it. It sold within a few months to a tourist couple from Paris. I have always regretted not buying it.
I did not take proactive steps that would have assisted my 20 year old brother during his battle with cancer.

When I was a sophomore in college, my Dad called as I was coordinating weekend plans with friends.  Since I was going to see him the next morning, I rushed the conversation and went off with my friends.  He had a heart attack and died before I got to see him.  I have always regretted not having more of a conversation with him that night.

Getting married.

regretList.regret:
I made an investment in cryptocurrency and had a plan to take out my profit after reaching a certain figure. That figure came and went, and I got greedy. I "made" more money in 2 months than I had made in the last 4 years, but I didn't cash out when I should have and lost 75% of my profits. On top of that, I'm stuck with a fat tax bill.

I've studied the psychology of money and understood it was important to have a plan, but when it came to the moment to act, I didn't. I regret not sticking to a plan and being happy with having "enough" instead of getting greedy.

I regret leaving a treasured relationship with a married man when I was 36, and moving from the east to the west coast to make it difficult to go home. I married someone else soon after and we are happy 34 years later. The married man stayed in touch until his 1st wife died, then he remarried and never contacted me again. I learned from a friend that he died on June 8th. Though I love my husband, sometimes I wish I'd never left the east.

When I was 20 years old in college, I was called to Hollywood numerous times for casting calls.  Agents were pushing me to move to LA to pursue an acting career, but I decided to stay where I was and finish college, and I always regretted not following that opportunity.

I regret playing it safe and getting a tedious, soulless corporate job, rather than pursue my dream off teaching for fear of not having enough money to pay tuition and bills. Now, at 44 I’m finally realizing that it’s in my DNA to teach. Everyday, in inexplicable ways I am coaching, guiding, mentoring, and teaching those around me. I’ve been doing it all along. While my corporate marketing career is one of moderate success with little satisfaction and great discontent.
Is it even possible to dream of a major career shift at 44? Am I being irrational? Then I hear the low, rhythmic, drum beat, that incessant reminder of a life unfulfilled.

I should have been direct and honest when a close friend of mine asked about something I had done that violated his trust. If I had been immediately and completely honest things might have been better.

i wish i was easier on myself and spent more time enjoying life and being proud of what ive already accomplished

Not trying harder to stay married to my first husband because of the impact that divorce has on kids.

I was in greater Tibet and nomad invited me to come with him, he gestured over the hills, off the road, to who knows where. I was on a schedule to go back to school but my mind has created infinite scenarios on where that journey would have taken me.

I wish I would have pursued a doctoral degree when I was younger.  If I had spent more time talking to professors when I was in undergrad then maybe I would have found one to inspire/encourage me.  As a first generation college student, I had no idea of what to do after college other than get a job.  I could have been a professor, done research to help make the world better, and collaborated with other thinkers across the world.

While in Utah some years back touring the National Parks, we stopped at Delicate Arch but did not hike all the way to the rock formation for various reasons. I wish I had taken the time. (This is symbolic of other choices I've made in life to not take the time to experience some location/event.)
I married a bum -  first marriage. I put him through college.
I am on my 3rd marriage, so marriage 1 and marriage 2.

I always loved holding my mother’s hand. After she passed away, I was unable to hold it one last time. She’s been gone over nine years and I regret not taking the opportunity to have physical contact with her for a final time. At 56 years old, I miss holding my mom’s hand.
I regret not appreciating my mother until she was gone.
Not untangling my upbringing more definitely and sooner.
I regret getting married too early and having kids too soon — I had a job I loved and had to leave it. I’ve always wondered what if I stayed?

I regret being too impatient to allow my kids to help me in the kitchen with cooking. Now as young adults they don't have any cooking skills or even know how to peel an apple, and not much interest to be in the kitchen.
I wish I would have been more attentive to communicating effectively and compassionately with my two ex-husbands, so we could have avoided divorce.
Not being more prepared for two career possibilities. Made assumptions that I could do the work without a comprehensive appraisal.

I regret having inhaled shisha once. I was on a 3 day trip in Dubai during the holidays, with my mother and stepfather. It was the 1st time I traveled to another continent. Every sequence that happened before that moment since I was invited, led me to this one thing. My stepfather worked for Air Canada (still does), so I knew only 10% of the flights had to be paid. In fact, they paid it so I didn't even have to pay a dime. Fast-forward starting from when we arrived at the big destination, it was already dark because of the different time zones. We first got to our hotel room. Then, the stepfather invited me to go out for a little while to get a meal. We sat there and there were a few shisha pumps that people were using. I talked a little bit about it to him, and then told me some things saying that it wouldn't make much difference if it was inhaled. He was confusing my brain and my state. Eventually, the decision in my mind was to do it and so I did. Just after, he did as well.

REGRET
I regret not saying “I love you” to my mother the last time I spoke to her, two hours before she unexpectedly died. That was eight years ago.

I regret not paying my life coach for our last session. I recall feeling sour toward her and maybe didn't like the guidance she was giving me (after 3+ years of excellent guidance) so I just didn't pay her. A couple years later, during the pandemic, she offered a free session to her past clients knowing many of them would be in turmoil and I had a session. She gently reminded me of the missed payment and I intended to pay, but didn't, again.  I now feel too ashamed to reach out and make good on my debt.
Getting married so young
I wish I had known that it wasn't me that was wrong/fucked up (in my family and relationships) all those years.  Reading Untamed by Glennon Doyle set me free.
choosing not to have another child

not going to medical school and becoming a doctor; my personal experience as a 10 years old spending 3 months in a hospital away from my family changed my mind about becoming a doctor

I regret that I did not travel across the country to meet my large extended family until I was over 50 years old. I missed out on meeting some wonderful people who had already passed away and who may have greatly enriched my life. I missed out on half a lifetime of love and connectedness to people who share my family history.
Not having sought help when I was assaulted, thinking that I could face my enemies without bothering others.

Overwelmed stong pass for The time protect and defend the helm protect The king
1. BE MORE ATTENTION 2. RISK MORE IN LIFE

For me it's a bit hard to say. For one hand I don't believe so much in the concept of regret. I like to think that every choice I made over the years are in a way responsible for who I'm today and I'm mostly proud of myself. So silly regrets like not learning a third language? Yes, but maybe "regret" is a strong word for that feeling. But in the end, wouldn't call it a regret itself but a wish. A wish to live life. I think although regret is a concept I don't fully "believe", is one that pushes me forward. The fear of regrets is more than a fuel than the regret itself. By the end I know I won't regret. I know that I'll do my best. As this idea, the need to avoid the regret, will keep me in line.
Having fear, playing safe and thus not making bolder choices

I regret not having the confidence in my own dreams and ambitions when I was younger.  I always wanted to write and 30 years later am coming back to it.  I just wonder what I could have done if I'd stuck at it then.
Taking the pill for so many years and not listening to my body. Not speaking my truth, e.g. to my loved ones, therefore again disappointing myself instead of others

being to hard

I was a fast runner in grade school and we moved in 5th grade to new a town that had a competitive running team.  I caught bronchitis in the first year and couldn't keep up so I never went back to the team.  I regret that dropping out made me miss out on having the experience of being part of an athletic team in high school.

I wish I had appreciated the short time I had with my great-grandmothers more when I was a kid. Now I would give anything for 15 minutes.

Ignoring warning signs and noticeable clues regarding my ex-wife when we dated years ago and thinking things would be better if we got married. We were married 15+ years but then divorced 11 years ago. It's a regret I was young and dumb and proud.

I DEEPLY regret not having admitted to myself that I am a Lesbian SOONER.  Instead of wasting years dating the wrong gender I could have been falling in love with the right one and having a much happier life.

I know this seems silly but I regret not upgrading to business class on a flight from CA to IN when I had the chance. I was 16 and it was only $30 but I thought my dad would kill me if I spent it on a seat upgrade rather than something else. To this day, I have never flown business class.

I had an opportunity for an internal move with my company.  At the same time I worked with a mentor/coach that recommended not telling my current supervisor about the opportunity for fear that he would try to stop me from making the move.  I regret not telling my supervisor because the decision caused long term damage to the relationship.
Not taking the path of playing pro baseball.

Years ago, I broke into my high school and stole some tests. A year after graduating, I was having lunch with a teacher who had thought highly of me and I shared/bragged about it because I thought it made me look smart. After I spoke, I could tell it broke her heart.

I regret I didn’t follow up on a teacher’s recommendation and investigate going to Georgetown University to study history. Instead I went to a nearby university. It lowered my sights and kept my world small.
I regret not going to college in California in the 1970's.
All my regrets are related to things I wish I would or wouldn't have said to people I cared about, and/or for time I didn't spend with peopleI care about that I can no longer spend time with.
Not trusting my own initial reactions or visceral responses more often. That first blink is usually pretty accurate.
I regret choosing to stay with an emotionally abusive man just because I’d made a vow.
Poor financial decisions such as taking out student loans to fund my education are one of my biggest regrets. I did not seriously look for other ways to pay for my undergraduate and graduate degrees.

I regret not spending more time with my parents. They've both passed away. I can't count the number of times I've said, "I wish mom was here to show me XX or help me with XX" or "I wish dad was here to explain how I'm related to XX or advise me about XX." Not only do I wish I'd spent more time with them, but I also wish I would have filmed them answering questions about our family.

A couple was in the process of adopting two boys from another country asked what they might expect, given that the babies had been abandoned, were infants, and early care was unknown, I responded too curtly.  I said that the children may well have learning and behavior problems.  Who can predict the future?
Going into education as a career. I was a first generation college student and there were teachers in my family so I did what I had been exposed to.
I regret putting so much emphasis on my career when my kids were young. Spending extra time working to advance my salary instead of spending that time with them when they were young.

not fostering strong friendships

Not being true to leading a life of my own, not standing up for myself and I not following my heart. I focused too much on others happiness and how my decisions would affect them instead of my own. Being afraid of hurting people than myself.
I regret doing what I thought I was "suppose to" for a large part of my life and not taking the unconventional risks that wouldn't have I wanted and others would have looked down upon
I regret committing to my ex-wife so early in my life (early 20's) before understanding and establishing my own core values
not having studied abroad

Regret that I didn't adjust my life focus to loved ones at their time of need, thinking there would always be time in the future - not once but Uncle Eric, Mom, Dad and Rick.  I regret the angst when dad lived with me and did something he thought was funny - that I couldn't let myself laugh with him.
I regret not having more years with my adventurous partner who travelled the world freely.

I regret that I didn’t know how to ask for help with studying foreign languages. I tried to learn three languages other than English, and could not progress beyond basics. I was too impatient and too resistant too working hard at something that did not come easily.

I write this during my 24th year in policing. When I was a new officer, we were looking for a felony suspect and Dispatch had broadcast the associated plate. An officer was behind a vehicle and asked if he had the right plate. I got on the air and said it was wrong. He let the car go. It WAS the right plate. I still regret that mistake.

shutting people out instead of confronting them about their treatment of me

My regret is that my ex-husband asked me to marry him when he knew (I didn't!) that he still carried a torch for his first girlfriend.  He is now married to her, but he could have saved me 35 years of financially supporting him and enduring his PTSD from service in Viet Nam.
Cutting my sister out of my life, in spite of the fact that she is a liar and a thief.
I regret telling the biological father of my child (my abuser) that they exist. There was nothing to gain from that and everything to lose.
Getting married too young.  Then divorced.
I regret that I married someone that wasn't in love with; both times.

i wish i had not pursued a recent romantic relationship. it was the first time i'd even thought about the possibility of love since my abusive husband left me more than 20 years ago. however, it was not the right time nor for the right reasons. my selfish actions damaged many critical relationships and hurt very important people in my life. should have been patient, thought more, felt less.

I took crib notes into exams all throughout my high school and college years.  This has bothered me f my whole life, since I started almost 50 years ago.  Except for this, I have led a very honest life.  I just never learned how to study properly.  I have never shared this with anyone and would feel so ashamed if my own children ever found out.  My wife died several years ago and I never shared this with her.
I regret not being more confident and pursuing my dreams with more intention.
I wish I would have not given up on pursuing who I believe was the love of my life.
I had the opportunity to purchase a professional baseball team when I was 23. The cost was $100,000 in 1984 and I just wasn’t smart enough at that age to dream big.
I regret losing contact with friends from the different chapters of my life

Not having the confidence to leave my place of employment to pursue higher levels of responsibility when it became evident it wasn’t going to happen where I was.  I had a great job at a great company. But I watched equally talented people get the big jobs at other firms and I regret not doing the same.
I let my Mom nap.  I should have tried to wake her up.  She had had a stroke.
I regret not telling Jenn that I had a crush on her.  I was too worried about our friendship and am left wondering if we could have been really good together.

I regret playing it safe right out of college and getting a practical job, instead of following my dreams and traveling the world, student loans be damned. I'm in a great financial place now, but years of comfort and stagnation have made me fear change. I fear I'm too old to do the whole "vagabonding" thing now.
Continuing in relationships that I know are not supporting me or my goals.
Not taking a particular job early in my career.
Not getting my mental health issues addressed sooner.  Then maybe I would have been able to meet a nice person to spend my life and have a family.
Not majoring in computer science in 2009. My life would have been in a different place. Well now I am self-studying CS. Let's see where this un lived life takes me.

I regret not finishing my college degree, even though I needed very few credits to do so. The company I was working for part-time offered me a full-time position, and I jumped at the chance to get a substantial promotion, make good money, and launch my career. 

Even though I did well at the company, I longed to be back in the classroom. I loved learning, I loved the humanities (my field of study), and I left it all behind for what? Money? Status? Achievement?

I had the opportunity to study abroad at Oxford through an exchange program in college.  I chose to stay at home and focus on the life plan and timeline I'd set for myself.  I learned later that the life plan everyone says is "normal" isn't what it is cracked up to be.  Adventure awaits, take it!
I regret that I judged my nephew and didn't just love him like he needed to be loved.
I regret accidentally causing my sister's death when we were children, and not getting professional help dealing with the guilt I still carry.
Dropping out of college

I went to an elite UK university, won a scholarship while there and looked set to go on to an academic career. That was my dream. But on the first day of finals I totally lost my nerve, panicked, missed the exams and went AWOL for a couple of days (regret 1). After tracking me down, my parents persuaded me to go back and complete the rest of my exams, which, out of guilt I did and so ended up with a mediocre degree (regret 2) - quite an achievement in the circumstances, I guess, but devastating for an incurable perfectionist like me. If only I'd either had the courage to turn up for the exams on day one and taken my chances or stuck to my decision to drop out at the 11th hour and saved myself further humiliation. But I did neither. I took the coward's path - twice in succession. They say you regret the things you didn't do more than those you did. But my 'sin' was both of commission and omission. After 40yrs, it's a double wound that has never healed. Time, you are not a great healer!

He became Keep Out from there and we grew to be great friends. He would eventually start coming right to our apartments door for his daily meals. He learned the feeding schedule and always showed up on time. I loved this cat and wanted to make him mine, but my husband and I already had 4 cats of our own. I regret not taking him in or at the very least catching him and taking him to a shelter. My husband and I finally got a house and moved out of state. I regrettably had to leave him behind. I think about him so often and I hope he found a loving and safe home. I miss him terribly.
